_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ChemDesign Corporation¿s Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
November 12, 2002

ChemDesign Corporation¿s (CDC) accidental release prevention policy is to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  The controls involve process design, equipment installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training.

CDC¿s emergency response policy is to maintain an emergency response plan and team capable of responding to and minimizing the effects of any chemical emergency that might occur at the facility.

CDC is a custom batch manufacturer of a wide variety of specialty organic chemicals for use by the agricultural, electronics, coatings and other industries worldwide.  CDC has 11 major buildings located on a 39-acre site.   

CDC operates processes containing chlorine, phosphorous oxychloride, and hydrazine in excess of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) threshold quantities.  Because of the variable production scheduling inherent in custom batch manufacturing, any or all of these processes may not actually be present on-site at any given time.

In a worst case scenario accident, all the chlorine contained in a cylinder could be released.  Based on the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) RMP*Comp computer program, such an accidental release could extend downwind far enough to affect off-site persons or the environment.

An alternative chlorine release scenario that would be more likely to occur than the worst case scenario could consist of a leak from a small hole in a chlorine cylinder or its valve.  Based on EPA's RMP*Comp computer program, such a release would not extend downwind far enough to affect off-site receptors.

An alternative phosphorous oxychloride release scenario that would be more likely to occur than the worst case scenario could consist of a leak from a small hole in the side of a phosphorous oxychloride drum.  Based on EPA's RMP*Comp computer program, such

a release would extend downwind far enough to affect immediately neighboring off-site industrial establishments.
 
An alternative hydrazine release scenario that would be more likely to occur than the worst case scenario could consist of a leak from a small hole in the side of a hydrazine hydrate drum.  Based on EPA's RMP*Comp computer program, such a release would extend downwind far enough to affect immediately neighboring off-site industrial establishments.              
                                
CDC¿s general accidental release prevention program minimizes the potential for any chemical incident.  CDC complies with OSHA¿s Process Safety Management regulations that include many requirements intended to prevent releases.  CDC¿s general accidental release prevention program consists of the following practices:

1.   Hazard and operability studies (HAZOP) or" What If?" reviews are conducted for all new processes
2.   Written operating procedures are used for all processes
3.   Employees are trained on new or changed processes and equipment
4.   Contractors are informed of hazards and required to follow plant safety rules
5.   Safe work practices are used, including lockout/tagout, confined space entry permits, line opening   permits, hot work permits, and contractor work permits
6.   Process or equipment changes require prior safety review and pre-startup inspection
7.   Process equipment is inspected, tested and maintained to insure mechanical integrity
8.   All incidents are investigated so that measures to prevent recurrence can be implemented
9.   The site is equipped with extensive fire protection equipment
10.  The site has a written emergency plan, emergency communications and equipment, and access to the services of employee, contractor and state hazardous material emergency responders
11.  The site is regularly inspected, audited and monitored 
12.  Engineers and/or chemists closely oversee initial operation of all new processes and equipment
13.  V

irtually the entire site is located within a barbed wire fence that has locked gates and badge-activated turnstiles. 
14.  A site safety committee meets monthly
 
A number of specific precautions and safety measures are employed to prevent occurrence of any chlorine releases and to minimize their consequences.  No flammable or combustible materials are stored or located near the chlorine cylinders.  The chlorine buildings are constructed of steel, are thermally insulated and are kept closed during chlorine usage.  The storage areas and evaporator buildings are protected from vehicle collisions by concrete-filled metal posts.  The chlorine is stored in DOT-approved steel cylinders.  The cylinders are leak-tested and inspected by the supplier before they are filled.  Respirators are worn by employees while connecting or disconnecting cylinders.  Chlorine cylinder patching and repair kits are readily available on-site.  Employee members of CDC's emergency response team are trained on the use of the kits.  Self-contained breathing apparatus, fully encapsulating suits and portable chlorine detectors are readily available for emergency use by employees responding to a chlorine leak.  Fixed chlorine detectors sound audible alarms and activate feed valve  interlocks in the event of chlorine leaks.  Chlorine pipelines are constructed of welded steel.  Scrubbers remove any chlorine that vents from the production processes.

A number of precautions and safety measures are employed to prevent occurrence of any phosphorous oxychloride releases and to minimize their consequences.  The phosphorous oxychloride drums are banded together three to a pallet so they cannot tip over.  The pallets are stored inside plastic tubs to contain any liquid leaks.  The drums are covered with plastic tarps to keep any liquid leaks inside the plastic tubs.  The building where phosphorous oxychloride is stored is equipped with monitored and pressure-boosted foam sprinklers and is locked when no empl

oyees are present.  The drum storage pad where phosphorous oxychloride is also stored is centrally located within the site's perimeter fencing and has overhead cover and a bermed concrete floor.  
                                                                                                                                                                            A number of precautions and safety measures are employed to prevent occurrence of any hydrazine releases and to minimize their consequences.  All hydrazine on-site is fully hydrated, i.e. all hydrazine is contained in water solutions having no more than a 64% hydrazine strength.  This measure significantly reduces the vapor and fire hazards.  The buildings where hydrazine hydrate containers and tanks are located are equipped with substantial secondary containment and with monitored and pressure-boosted sprinklers.  The drum storage pad where hydrazine hydrate containers are also stored has overhead cover and a bermed concrete floor.  All tanks are equipped with rupture disks that relieve into containment tanks outside the buildings.  Scrubbers remove any hydrazine that vents from the production processes.
            
There have been no chlorine, phosphorous oxychloride or hydrazine releases over the last 5 years that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on site, or offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.   
 
The fire departments of two municipalities (Fitchburg and Westminster) respond to site emergencies.  Numerous fire pull stations throughout the site, as well as sprinkler water flow alarms, automatically alert the fire departments.  Numerous portable dry chemical fire extinguishers throughout the site are available for the immediate use of all employees, who are annually provided fire extinguisher training.  An on-site employee emergency response team is trained and equipped to handle most spills or releases.

An on-site emergency command center is fully equipped with radios and telephones for close cooperation of CDC¿s emergency response team with the fire departments in an emergency.  Four emergency response drills are conducted each year with the fire departments.  Two weather stations are located on-site to provide immediate information on wind speed and direction.  Windsocks installed on several buildings also provide wind direction.  All site supervisors and operators are equipped with portable radios.  A site public address system allows instant communication with most site employees.  A number of CDC managers, including safety and environmental, are always on-call via cellular phones or beepers.  The site¿s gas release siren is audible up to half a mile away.

CDC continually plans changes to improve safety at its site.  Current plans include:

1.  Adoption of a formal environmental management system
2.  Training of additional employees as emergency responders
3.  Establishment of a safety observation program
4.  Possible installation of additional physical security measures
